Get started with funbiogeo

Source: vignettes/funbiogeo.Rmd
funbiogeo.Rmd
library("funbiogeo")

The aim of the package funbiogeo is to help users with analyses in FUNctional BIOGEOgeography (Violle et al. 2014). It helps to load and combine data, computing trait coverage, as well as computing functional diversity indices, drawing maps, correlate them with the environment, and upscaling assemblages.

Data format

The package funbiogeo requires that information be spread into three datasets:

  • the sites x locations dataset (example dataset: sites_locs)
  • the sites x species dataset (example dataset: sites_occs)
  • the species x traits dataset (example dataset: species_traits)

Let’s take a look at each of these datasets.

Sites x Locations

This dataset contains spatial coordinates of sites (points) of the study area. It can be either a matrix or a data.frame and row names must contain sites names. It must contain at least two columns: the longitude and the latitude of sites. This dataset must contain unique sites. Additional columns are accepted must will be ignored by funbiogeo.

The package funbiogeo comes with the example dataset sites_locs.

## Load sites x locations example dataset ----
data("sites_locs", package = "funbiogeo")
Format of sites x locations dataset
longitude latitude
MD_9557550010661 -76.77747 39.72233
MD_9565278010661 -79.38865 39.72230
NJ_9687057010661 -75.05517 40.36122
OH_19104898010661 -80.41646 41.88894
PA_10725597010661 -76.94414 40.58342
PA_10725883010661 -76.69413 40.44453
PA_10725971010661 -76.66636 40.22231
PA_10726115010661 -76.69413 40.52786
PA_10726148010661 -76.63858 40.52787
PA_10726179010661 -76.86081 40.33342 
## Row names contain sites names ----
rownames(sites_locs)[1:4]
#> [1] "MD_9557550010661"  "MD_9565278010661"  "NJ_9687057010661" 
#> [4] "OH_19104898010661"

To create your own sites x locations dataset you can use the function fb_format_sites_locations(). See below the section Long format.

Sites x Species

This dataset contains species occurrences/abundance/coverage at sites (points) of the study area. It can be either a matrix or a data.frame and row names must contain sites names. Columns must contain only species distribution information and sites must be unique. No additional columns are accepted.

The package funbiogeo comes with the example dataset species_occs.

## Load sites x species example dataset ----
data("species_occs", package = "funbiogeo")
Format of sites x species dataset
acer_negundo acer_nigrum acer_pensylvanicum acer_rubrum
MD_9557550010661 0 0 0 14
MD_9565278010661 0 0 0 7
NJ_9687057010661 0 0 0 6
OH_19104898010661 0 0 0 6
PA_10725597010661 0 0 0 4
PA_10725883010661 0 0 0 28
PA_10725971010661 0 0 0 0
PA_10726115010661 0 0 0 3
PA_10726148010661 0 0 0 5
PA_10726179010661 0 0 0 8 
## Row names contain sites names ----
rownames(species_occs)[1:4]
#> [1] "MD_9557550010661"  "MD_9565278010661"  "NJ_9687057010661" 
#> [4] "OH_19104898010661"
## Column names contain species names ----
colnames(species_occs)[1:4]
#> [1] "acer_negundo"       "acer_nigrum"        "acer_pensylvanicum"
#> [4] "acer_rubrum"

To create your own sites x species dataset you can use the function fb_format_sites_species(). See below the section Long format.

Species x Traits

This dataset contains traits values for studied species. It can be either a matrix or a data.frame and row names must contain species names. Columns must contain only traits variables and species must be unique. No additional columns are accepted.

Note that traits values cannot vary across sites for a given species.

The package funbiogeo comes with the example dataset species_traits.

## Load species x traits example dataset ----
data("species_traits", package = "funbiogeo")
Format of species x traits dataset
sla n_mass wood_dens
acer_negundo 26.91535 2.500345 0.416
acer_pensylvanicum 25.26650 2.221026 0.440
acer_rubrum 15.88968 1.657609 0.490
acer_saccharum 14.21417 1.497401 0.560 
## Row names contain species names ----
rownames(species_traits)[1:4]
#> [1] "acer_negundo"       "acer_pensylvanicum" "acer_rubrum"       
#> [4] "acer_saccharum"
## Column names contain traits names ----
colnames(species_traits)
#> [1] "sla"       "n_mass"    "wood_dens"

To create your own species x traits dataset you can use the function fb_format_species_traits(). See below the section Long format.

Long format

If your data are not spread into three datasets you can use the functions fb_format_*() to create these specific datasets. This implies that your data are structured into a long table, i.e. one row corresponds to the occurrence/abundance/coverage of one species at one site. This also implies that some variables are repeated across the table (e.g. sites coordinates, species traits).

Let’s take an example

## Path to example raw dataset ----
filename <- system.file("extdata", "raw_trees_data.csv", package = "funbiogeo")

## Read CSV file ----
all_data <- read.csv2(filename)
Long table example
site species longitude latitude count sla n_mass wood_dens
PA_76856094010538 acer_pensylvanicum -78.60508 39.91707 7 25.2665 2.221026 0.44
PA_68287127010538 acer_pensylvanicum -77.54087 40.35293 2 25.2665 2.221026 0.44
PA_76855646010538 acer_pensylvanicum -78.30221 40.18796 4 25.2665 2.221026 0.44
PA_58581106010538 acer_pensylvanicum -79.28570 40.04243 2 25.2665 2.221026 0.44
PA_145019955010661 acer_pensylvanicum -77.05348 40.37183 3 25.2665 2.221026 0.44
PA_10716167010661 acer_pensylvanicum -78.30529 41.02784 1 25.2665 2.221026 0.44
PA_58581599010538 acer_pensylvanicum -76.53834 41.48055 7 25.2665 2.221026 0.44
PA_10752222010661 acer_pensylvanicum -78.86086 41.13895 2 25.2665 2.221026 0.44
PA_10789064010661 acer_pensylvanicum -77.83305 41.66673 2 25.2665 2.221026 0.44
PA_58581253010538 acer_pensylvanicum -76.64231 41.34820 1 25.2665 2.221026 0.44


  • Format sites x locations data

The function fb_format_sites_locations() extracts sites coordinates from this long table to create the sites x locations dataset. Note that one site must have one unique longitude x latitude value.

## Format sites x locations data ----
sites_locations <- fb_format_sites_locations(data      = all_data, 
                                             site      = "site", 
                                             longitude = "longitude", 
                                             latitude  = "latitude",
                                             na_rm     = FALSE)

## Preview ----
head(sites_locations)
#>                   longitude latitude
#> OH_19104898010661 -80.41646 41.88894
#> PA_10686546010661 -78.22196 40.11119
#> PA_10686882010661 -78.33307 40.19452
#> PA_10688091010661 -78.49974 39.86120
#> PA_10688665010661 -78.47196 40.22230
#> PA_10688975010661 -78.36085 40.08341


  • Format sites x species data

The function fb_format_sites_species() extracts species occurrence/abundance/coverage from this long table to create the sites x species dataset. Note that one species must have been observed one time at one site (the package funbiogeo does not yet consider temporal survey).

## Format sites x species data ----
sites_species <- fb_format_sites_species(data       = all_data, 
                                         site       = "site", 
                                         species    = "species", 
                                         value      = "count",
                                         na_to_zero = TRUE)

## Preview ----
head(sites_species)
#>                    acer_pensylvanicum populus_tremuloides quercus_macrocarpa
#> PA_76856094010538                   7                   0                  0
#> PA_68287127010538                   2                   0                  0
#> PA_76855646010538                   4                   0                  0
#> PA_58581106010538                   2                   0                  0
#> PA_145019955010661                  3                   0                  0
#> PA_10716167010661                   1                   0                  0


  • Format species x traits data

The function fb_format_species_traits() extracts species traits values from this long table to create the species x traits dataset. Note that one species must have one unique trait value (no trait variation across sites allowed).

## Format species x traits data ----
species_traits <- fb_format_species_traits(data    = all_data, 
                                           species = "species", 
                                           traits  = c("sla", "n_mass", "wood_dens"))

## Preview ----
species_traits
#>                          sla   n_mass wood_dens
#> acer_pensylvanicum  25.26650 2.221025      0.44
#> populus_tremuloides 15.06333 2.027469      0.35
#> quercus_macrocarpa  11.01700 2.302263      0.58
